thread.title: Plymouth Herald reporter tells of 'three minutes of nothing' in...

author: DanielClark
title: Plymouth Herald reporter tells of 'three minutes of nothing' in...
text:
Plymouth Herald reporter tells of 'three minutes of nothing' in interview with Theresa May By DanielClark | Posted: June 01, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (0) 
The encounter of the chief reporter for Plymouth Herald with the Prime Minister Theresa May has made national headlines after she said 'three minutes of nothing'. 
Theresa May has been accused by some of sounding monotonous on the campaign trail and has also faced criticism for her decision to duck out of the Leaders' Debate on BBC1 on Wednesday night. — Liberal Democrats (@LibDems) May 31, 2017 
She visited Plymouth on Wednesday, but the encounter of her interview with the chief reporter for Plymouth Herald Sam Blackledge has made national headlines after he said that she managed to get through a whole interview without saying anything. Read more Judge to rule on Devon Tory candidate fraud case hours before... 
He told the Plymouth Herald that he was pleased to have secured the interview and happy to have squeezed all my points in, but added: "no sooner had the ministerial car pulled away from Sutton Harbour than I began to feel a bit deflated. 
"If the ultimate job of a journalist is to get answers, I had failed. Should I have stopped her and demanded she be more specific? Could I have gone full angry Paxman , or brought the interview to an abrupt close in protest? 
"Back at the office, we scratched our heads and wondered what the top line was. 
"She had and given me absolutely nothing. It was like a postmodern version of Radio 4's Just A Minute." Judge to rule on Devon Tory candidate fraud case hours before... 
The interview in full is: 
Sam: Two visits in six weeks to one of the country's most marginal constituencies – is she getting worried? 
Theresa: "I'm very clear that this is a crucial election for this country." 
Sam: Plymouth is feeling the effects of military cuts. Will she guarantee to protect the city from further pain? 
Theresa: "I'm very clear that Plymouth has a proud record of connection with the armed forces." 
Sam: How will your Brexit plan make Plymouth better off? 
Theresa: "I think there is a better future ahead for Plymouth and for the whole of the UK." 
Sam: Will you promise to sort out our transport links? 
Theresa: "I'm very clear that connectivity is hugely important for Plymouth and the South West generally."
